author: @BringBackGulags
text: I was born in Russia. My grandfather was a Jew from Kiev. Grandmother is from Belarus. Parents are from Russia. Literally everyone in Russian is proud of their Soviet heritage, even the Orthodox Christians. So when someone claims to represent Russians and and are trash talking Stalin, know they they are full of shit. No, the KGB wasnt hiding under your bed. Usually people who talk like that were not born in the USSR or were too young to remember it, and theyre usually Ukrainian, Jewish, or Baltic. Post Soviet countries are propagandized by western media.

author: @dorothydepth000
text:
The power vacuum is impossible. Either you have "the power of the government" (which you, as citizens, CAN control even if it's a bourgeois government, still, you have a degree of power. And if it's a people's government you definitely can control it).

Or you will have the power of the private corporations. And you have zero control over those.

So. You choose. Would you rather have a degree of power (a state and a government) or no power at all. Because when the corporations outgrow the state and get to disband it... You're f*cked.

"Economic freedom" is the freedom for the corporations to rule over you.

author: @likeabossk4055
text: 15:32 One thing he doesn't seem to understand is that caring for the people is caring for the people of the earth, he seems only concerned about the "uncomfortable position" that the Soviets would have to go to war to save Afghan civilians at the expense of Soviet service men. (Which also gives me a vibe that he sees them as lesser people in some sense and that they don't deserve the help). Afghanistan requested aid from the Soviets, being a caring neighbour and friend of their people they decided to help. His argument of saying that the Soviet's stance to protect a friend was wrong and stupid, is a very selfish way to look at it and reminds me of the American narratives around the "divide and conquer" strategy, which could be what he has fallen victim to.

replies.author: @MiroRaitamaa
replies.text:
@vannajs5024Â  It's not clear at all. Ilyin was a Nazi collaborator and a monarchist, but his philosophical views are much more complex and contradicting to his actions irl. He was a staunch anti-capitalist, didn't agree with the notion of private property, opposed western style racism and induvidualism, etc. His views originated from Orthodoxy, not from biological determination or paganism unlike Nazism, as far as I've read him.
What tenets of Ilyins thought is Putin interested about?

replies.author: @domashnie_lubimtsy
replies.text:
@MiroRaitamaa numbers! Look up economic data: production volumes, structure of export, level of poverty, food consumption levels, etc. See comparative charts of Russian empire, Soviet union and Russian federation. Look up financing of budget items and median salaries. There's no way a Marxist will call a country undepaying its teachers and underfunding its science one with even slight socialist tendencies. 
Yes, workers rights are oppressed, but this is hard to measure, especially without solid statistics. But economic indicators don't lie.

replies.author: @vannajs5024
replies.text: @MiroRaitamaa Illyn's philosophy its similar to philosophy of Serbian right wing,Nazi collaborator Dimitrije Ljotic,Anti capitalism, Nationalistic worldview,derived from Orthodox Mysticism,but at the same time,strong anti marxist stance, Illyn's famous quote "It's the USSR,not Russia",Which he called Holly Russia.Similar reactionary standpoint had Fyodor Dostoyevsky Anti Westernism ,but from a reactionary point of view.

replies.author: @domashnie_lubimtsy
replies.text:
@MiroRaitamaa Hitler also had anti-capitalist rhetoric. Are modern day marxists so easy to manipulate? 
Ilyin is not the only one. Read Dugin, Prokhanov, etc. Almost every official spreads Goebbels' view on historical facts, collaborators get new memorials, Soviet names of streets are changed, nazi formations take "help" the police deal with immigrants, strike leaders get arrested before strike begins, you can get real long prison sentence for criticism of the government and its actions on your social network page, but go free after a couple of years of house arrest for economic crimes like stealing several millions from said government. This year reborn Black Hundred congratulated us with November 7th  and said: you lost, we won. And they are right.

replies.author: @dorothydepth000
replies.text:
â€‹@vannajs5024if you only look at what he is saying, then, yeah, sure.

But words are wind. You actually need to look at what Putin is doing. In practice. More state control in economics and especially industrial production, more working jobs (as opposed to bullshit jobs), more state control in education, more state control in culture, economic and military aid to anti-colonial struggle, etc. etc.

In words, and even in his heart, he might be the worst anti-communist ever. But as Stalin said: Ð»Ð¾Ð³Ð¸ÐºÐ° Ð¾Ð±ÑÑ‚Ð¾ÑÑ‚ÐµÐ»ÑŒÑÑ‚Ð² ÑÐ¸Ð»ÑŒÐ½ÐµÐµ Ð»Ð¾Ð³Ð¸ÐºÐ¸ Ð½Ð°Ð¼ÐµÑ€ÐµÐ½Ð¸Ð¹. You can build all kinds of dream castles in your head, but the logic of the entirety of our history drives us towards a socialist future. There is simply no other route our history can take.

Even Putin's economic advisors know that. Have you read "ÐšÑ€Ð¸ÑÑ‚Ð°Ð»Ð» Ñ€Ð¾ÑÑ‚Ð°"? That's the future and we're getting there.

author: @KilroyishereYT
text:
The contexts... the times...
We can compare Stalin to Lenin and certainly not Putin or Xi to these two historical leaders. But in Putin there is a certain novelty that was missing from all the leaders of the past... except Chavez... in fact Chavez was one of Putin's mentors.
For the first time, I want to use the word â€œpragmatismâ€ positively... pragmatic, normally without principles, but Putin's pragmatism is another thing.
In fact, Putin understood "the thing"... In the West, leaders for a while have been showing left to strike right and I have the impression that Putin is doing the opposite. I don't think he's a believer but in church he makes his little gesture of the cross... in my opinion he doesn't care about the homosexuality problem but he uses it to oppose generic imperialist politicians.
On the other hand, he nationalized key sectors in a non-violent way, by applying prices, taxes, complex regulations, etc. He helps without making too much noise to countries victims of imperialism... â€œgiving ICBMs to North Korea was a bit noisy all the sameâ€.
